Sentence: Danny is the son of Reb Saunders, the pious and revered head of a great Hasidic dynasty
On their first Sabbath together, Danny introduces Reuven to his (Danny) father, Rabbi Isaac Saunders
Reuven witnesses a strange ritual: Reb Saunders quizzes Danny in public during their congregation's Sabbath meal
Danny and Reuven begin spending most afternoons together in the library and Saturdays studying Talmud with Reb Saunders
After David Malter gives a highly publicized pro-Zionist speech at Madison Square Garden, Reb Saunders, who is staunchly anti-Zionist, forbids Danny from speaking to Reuven

Finally, during Reuven and Danny's third year of college, after the United Nations officially declares the creation of the State of Israel and after it becomes clear that Israel will triumph in its battles against the Arabs, Reb Saunders relents and allows the two boys to speak to each other again
Over the summer, Reuven returns to Danny's shul, goes to Danny's sister's wedding, and sees Reb Saunders again
During the boys' final year at college, Reuven sees Reb Saunders while attending Danny's brother's Bar Mitzvah, and again the rabbi invites Reuven over
One night, after a discussion with his (Danny) father, Reuven realizes that Reb Saunders is asking him (Saunders) to come over so he (Saunders) can indirectly talk to Danny
Reuven goes to their house, and Reb Saunders, using Reuven as a buffer to speak to Danny, finally explains why he (Danny) raised Danny in silence
Reb Saunders further reveals that he (Danny) is aware of Danny's plan to become a psychologist instead of a rabbi
